# 04. The code, unwritten 

 The idea of "the greatest good for the greatest number" is at least *prima facie* intuitively appealing. 

 And as soon as it is agreed that ethical action should be guided by outcomes, it reduces complex ethical dilemmas down to a technocratic calculation of the potential outcomes each action might result in. 

 We could delve into the literature in psychology, economics, statistics, among others – to arrive at fairly decent numerical estimates of the proposed actions – and the ethical course of action is simply picking the one with the biggest number attached to its outcomes. 

 Understandably, it is often incredibly difficult to argue against utilitarian ethic. 

 But undoubtedly, there is clearly something deeply lacking in utilitarianism (and consequentialism in general).

Danny wakes up from the utilitarian nightmare and finds a person sitting next to him. 

 "Did someone tell you getting drunk was unethical?" 

 Danny sits up. In front of him is an old man. 

 His name, is John Locke. 

 " Utilitarianism however is not the only framework of moral philosophy. Far from it." He assures Danny. 

 There is yet hope still...
All mankind... being all equal and independent, no one ought to harm another in his *life, health, liberty or possessions*.
slides.reference: Source: Locke, J. (1689). *Second treatise of government*.

slides.text:
Central to John Locke's theory is the concept of **Natural Rights**. 

 His reasoning is as follows: 

 - Locke begins by imagining a state where there are no governments or laws, and people existed purely in a state of nature. 

 - In this state, he argues, individuals are free and equal, and any law or rights that might arise in a situation like this are inherent to nature, and is independent of any social or political institutions. 

 - Hence, nature is instructing human beings how to behave, and these laws are known as **Natural rights**. 

 - These rights are therefore bestowed to us by nature (and nature is obviously bigger than us), and so they cannot be taken away. That is to say, these natural rights are **inalienable**. 

 In this sense (and as a tangent), nature as a source of law is distinguishable from *divine law* which, in the Christian tradition, is a set of laws passed down from God. I mean, one *could* always resort to religion to defeat utilitarianism. But that'd be boring. And it clearly won't convince the utilitarians who are also atheists.

Following this chain of reasoning, Locke eventually concluded that there are 3 rights inherent to nature: 

 - **Life**, because in a state of nature self-preservation is the paramount goal; 

 - **Liberty**, because we own ourselves; 

 - **Property**, because we need things to survive.

 The natural rights to life and liberty are fairly straightforward. But property is a bit more complex: 

 - In a state of nature, we own ourselves. 

 - Therefore, we own our labour.

 - If we work on something, we mix our labour with it and extends our self ownership to it. 

 - Therefore anything we work on, we own.
The natural liberty of man is to be free from any superior power on Earth, and not to be under the will or legislative authority of man, but to have only **the law of nature** for his rule.
slides.reference: Source: Locke, J. (1689). *Second treatise of government*.

slides.text:
This idea that we have certain inviolable rights is called **Deontology**. 

 In contrast to utilitarianism, which is a **results based morality**, deontology can be aptly described as a framework for **rights-based morality**. 

 - Utilitarianism considers results and results only; Deontology considers the action in itself.

 - Utilitarians consider an action to be moral if it delivers the greatest good for the greatest number; deontologists consider an action to be moral if it does not violate any rights. 

- Utilitarianism aims to maximise wellbeing; deontology is about following rules of morality that are universally binding.  

 The two frameworks of morality couldn't be more different from one another. In fact, during many classic philosophical inquiries they are commonly understood in the context of one another.

 Source: Alexander, L., & Moore, M. (2020, October 30). *Deontological Ethics*. Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy.

slides.dialogueText: Perhaps the most well known example, the US Bill of Rights, is a direct application of deontological morality.
slides.reference: United States Courts. (2019, December 12). *Now Cherished, Bill of Rights Spent a Century in Obscurity.* United States Courts. https://www.uscourts.gov/news/2019/12/12/now-cherished-bill-rights-spent-century-obscurity

slides.text:
Understandably so, the utilitarians didn't like the idea very much. 

 Or maybe, that's precisely how deontological ethics is intended to work... 

 When the utilitarians set out to achieve the greatest good for the greatest numbers, their efforts are thwarted by inalienable rights. 

 Fortuitously. John Locke was over a hundred years before Jeremy Bentham. And when Jeremy Bentham was still alive, he *clearly* wasn't very impressed by Locke's ideas of natural rights...
Natural rights is simple nonsense: natural and imprescriptible rights, rhetorical nonsense — *nonsense upon stilts*.
slides.reference: Anarchical Fallacies in J. Bowring (ed.) Works vol. 2 (1843)

slides.text:
Ouch, spicy words coming from the godfather figure of utilitarianism. In his relentless attack on deontology, Bentham's main arguments were: 

 - "Natural rights" are an illusion because they exist only in the mind and cannot be enforced or observed without legal frameworks. 

 - That rights are created and enforced by law and legal institutions. 

- Therefore what Locke framed as "Natural Rights" are actually *Natural Laws*, not moral rules.
Right, the substantive right, is the child of law; from real laws come real rights; but from imaginary laws, from "laws of nature," come imaginary rights.
slides.reference: Anarchical Fallacies in J. Bowring (ed.) Works vol. 2 (1843)

slides.text:
And finally, as a hard utilitarian himself, using his own consequentialist theory: 

 - If everybody had natural rights, anarchy will be the result, which is bad. Unless if you're an anarchist of course. But there aren't that many of you anyway...
Natural rights and natural justice are from the very foundation of their structure, anarchical, and promotive of confusion in the highest degree.
slides.reference: Anarchical Fallacies in J. Bowring (ed.) Works vol. 2 (1843)

slides.text: Good ol' Jeremy, showing no quarters to his ideological opponents. Not even to the French when they were neck deep in their revolution...
The expressions employed…are so vague and indeterminate as to be susceptible of any one meaning, and in effect of no meaning at all.

slides.reflectionText: Bentham's comment on Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen (1789). (French: *Déclaration des droits de l'Homme et du citoyen de 1789*)

slides.text:
Jeremy Bentham's attack on the Lockean concept of Natural Rights was fierce, pragmatic, uncompromising. And he made good points. 

 Is the idea of rights doomed before it could begin? 

 Unbeknownst to him, a separate breed of Deontology was being developed in Europe. One does not need to depend on the idea of natural or legal rights. 

 And it was a heavy weight philosopher, perhaps the GOAT of philosophers. ("greatest of all time"). 

 His name, was Immanuel Kant. His method,  *pure reason*.

Now, a point needs to be made here before we could progress further in Kantian Deontology. 

 Thus far, we've been talking about **rights**. Of course, people love to talk about the idea of rights. But deontologists talk instead in terms of **duties**. 

 If we look at the word "deontology " it came from the Greek words "δέον" or "deon" meaning "duty", plus "λόγος" meaning "study" – i.e. the "study of duty". 

 The reason is simple: one person's rights is *always* someone else's duties. 

 For instance, my right to property is someone else's duty to not steal from me. My right to be free from starvation is someone else's duty to feed me. 

 This is known as the **Correlativity of Rights and Duties.** 

 Deontologists talk about duties instead of rights, because rights arise as a result of other people's duties. Because your right is always someone else's duties.
slides.reference: Beauchamp, T. L., & Feinberg, J. (1980). *The relationship between rights and duties: The fundamental principle of justice*. Education and the Legal System (pp. 231–022).

slides.text:
In addition, deontologists make a distinction between two types of moral duties: Negative duties, and Positive duties. 

- Negative duties are obligations to refrain from certain actions. For instance:

    - Duty to not cause harm to others

    - Duty to not steal from others

    - Duty not to lie

- Positive duties are obligations to actively do something to the benefit of others.

    - Duty to feed those who are hungry

    - Duty to defend people form crimes 

    - Duty to vote every 3 years

 This distinction is extremely important, as Kantians deontologists believe that they apply differently:

 - Negative duties are "Categorical Imperatives", meaning they are unconditional moral laws that always and universally apply. 

 - Positive duties are "Hypothetical Imperatives", meaning that they apply only in certain hypothetical conditions under *such and such circumstances*.
slides.reference: Johnson, R., & Cureton, A. (2022, January 21). *Kant’s Moral Philosophy*. Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral/

slides.text:
To understand the idea of a Categorical Imperative, we need to look at how Kant derived the set of Categorical Imperatives. 

 Kant's argument essentially goes something like this: 

 - Human beings are capable of **pure reason** – i.e. logical thinking, rationality, etc. Which is something other beings do not possess. This is the distinguishing characteristic of a human being apart from, say, animals or plants or rocks. 

 - This capacity for this pure reason is what gives human beings their intrinsic worth, or *dignity*.

 - Therefore, moral rules derived from pure reason holds a unique and central position in human existence and is binding at all times.

 In short, instead of relying on Natural law as the source of morality, Kant relied on pure reason as the source of morality. 

 OK then, how would one go about deriving these moral rules out of pure reason? 

 The starting point, is surprisingly simple...
slides.reference: Johnson, R., & Cureton, A. (2021). *Kant’s Moral Philosophy* (E. N. Zalta, Ed.). Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral

slides.text: Act only according to that maxim whereby you can, at the same time, will that it should become a universal law.
slides.reflectionText:
This is known as the Formula of the Universal Law. 

 Essentially, what Kant was trying to do is to find the equivalent of "I think, therefore I am" in ethics, which applies to all persons across all cultures. 

 Next, he goes on...
slides.reference: Kant, I. (1785). *Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals.*

slides.text: Act in such a way that you treat humanity, whether in your own person or in the person of any other, always at the same time as an end, never merely as a means.
slides.reflectionText: This is known as the **Humanity Formulation** holding that human beings **are ends to themselves**, and **should never be used as a means to an end.**
slides.reference: Kant, I. (1785). *Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals.*

slides.text:
In other words, human beings have **intrinsic moral worth**. 

 Why? Because human beings are capable of *pure reason*. This is a universal quality of human beings, and therefore in recognition of this shared rational capacity the autonomy of pure reason should be respected. 

 Continuing on...
Act so that your will can regard itself at the same time as making universal law through its maxims.
slides.reflectionText:
This is known as the Autonomy Formulation of Kant's categorical imperative. Because we are capable of pure reason, we are capable of self-directed rational behaviour and we can adopt and pursue our own ends. When we act morally, we're not just acting according to some external rules, laws, or impulses, but rather in accordance with our own rationality. 

 And finally...
slides.reference: Kant, I. (1785). *Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals.*

slides.text: Act according to maxims of a universally legislating member of a merely possible kingdom of ends.
slides.reference: Kant, I. (1785). *Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals.*

slides.text:
This is known as the Formula of the Kingdom of Ends. 

 Not to be confused with any kind of consequentialism, that's not what Kant means. 

 Kant imagines a world where all individuals are effectively legislators of moral laws – whatever people "legislate" as a moral law, everybody will follow. As these moral laws bind on all other rational wills they form a "systematic union of different rational beings under common laws" 

 Fundamentally, this means that we should act only in ways that are acceptable in such a community of different rational beings, where everybody is capable of being a legislator of the moral laws of the community – in a weird game theoretic way, perhaps it may sound.
slides.reference: Johnson, R., & Cureton, A. (2021). *Kant’s Moral Philosophy* (E. N. Zalta, Ed.). Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral

slides.text: So what does this all boil down to?

We've seen the four formulations of the Categorical Imperative: 

 - The Formula of the Universal Law 

 - The Humanity Formula 

 - The Autonomy Formula 

 - The Formula of the Kingdom of Ends. 

 Now here is the interesting part. Kant would say that all of these laws are perfect equivalents of each other. He gave detailed reasonings in his work, *Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals*, the derivation of which is beyond the scope of this exegesis. 

 But let's look at how we might apply these formulations to derive a categorical imperative...
slides.reference: as cited.

slides.text:
Suppose I'm considering lying in order to scam $100 worth of groceries. I might say that the product is faulty to get my money back, but in fact it isn't. 

 1) First, formulate a rule-based maxim from the proposed course of action. 

    - My proposed maxim is therefore, "Lying is moral if it benefits me." 

 2) Second, extend this maxim to all human beings, universally without exception. 

    - OK, now everybody lies whenever it benefits them.

 3) Test for logical consistency, self consistency, and against the 4 formulations. 

    - We are treating people not as ends in itself, but as means to an end (Breach of the Humanity Formula). 

    - We now have a world where truth or falsehood could no longer be determined. This creates a world where logical deduction is impossible. 

 Therefore a community of rational beings would not accept this rule. (Breach of the formula of the Kingdom of Ends) 

 Therefore, the maxim that "lying is moral if it benefits me" cannot be a categorical imperative, or a negative duty.

At this point, you might say that all of this sounds very abstract. How are we meant to apply this in everyday life? 

 Now here is the best part about all this Categorical Imperative stuff. Over the centuries since Kant formulated the them, philosophers have went on an exhaustive search. The result, is a list of duties best summarised by W. D. Ross: 

 - Duty to not cause harm 

 - Duty to not tell lies

 - Duty to repair damage done

 - Duty to not cause injustice

 These are the negative duties, i.e. categorical imperatives, that one should follow at all time, universally, and without exception. If one can do that, one is acting ethically.
slides.reference: Ross, W. D. (1930). *The Right and the Good*. Oxford University Press.

slides.text:
Now we've seen what negative duties, are we have previously also mentioned the idea of positive duties. Put simply, positive duties are "nice to haves", and can only be morally carried out if they **do not contradict a negative duty**. 

 For this reason, they are also called Imperfective Duties. Some of these positive duties include: 

 - Duty of Beneficence: help others, when and if it does not breach a negative duty.

 - Duty of Gratitude: Thank others for their help, when and if it does not breach a negative duty. 

 - Duty of Self-Improvement: practice virtue ethics, when and if it does not breach a negative duty.

 So how does it all fit together?
slides.reference: Johnson, R., & Cureton, A. (2021). *Kant’s Moral Philosophy* (E. N. Zalta, Ed.). Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral

slides.text:
In short, Deontological morality requires us to: 

 - Follow negative duties at all times without exception (Categorical Imperatives)

 - Carry out positive duties when and if it does not contradict a negative duty (Hypothetical Imperatives)

 If we can do that, then, according to deontological ethics, we would be acting ethically.
slides.reference: Johnson, R., & Cureton, A. (2021). *Kant’s Moral Philosophy* (E. N. Zalta, Ed.). Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy; Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral

slides.text:
Both Utilitarianism and Deontology are incredibly powerful frameworks of morality, because they allow objective determination of morality. 

 Objective morality provides a framework that is consistent, stable, and universal. They allow for accountability and facilitates the resolution of conflicts and disagreements through an impersonal and objective standard. 

 One could of course try to argue that morality is subjective. This leads to Moral Relativism – where morality is subjective, contextual, and is *relative* to the traditions, convictions, or practices of a group of individuals. 

 But subjective morality leads to tyranny, and arbitrariness of morality. 

 After all, if "morality is what I say" then the word morality loses meaning. Without the moral constraints, and without a common objective standard of morality, it is even *more difficult* to resolve moral difficulties, and we will all die very quickly.
slides.reference: Gowans, C. (2021, March 10). *Moral Relativism (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)*. Stanford.edu. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/

slides.text:
But then here is the **central finding** of this exegesis. 

 All ethical dilemmas and political conflicts are a clash between the principles of utilitarianism vs deontology. They represent fundamentally different principles of morality that cannot find any compromise between them. 

 History has demonstrated that neither could defeat the other, only momentarily subdue their antithesis, after which the backlash is even harder.

Left-wing zealots have often been prepared to ride roughshod over due process and basic considerations of fairness when they think they can get away with it. For them the ends always seems to justify the means. That is precisely how their predecessors came to create the gulag.
slides.reference: Thatcher, M. (2002). *Statecraft: Strategies for a changing world*. HarperCollins. Image from *Margaret Thatcher Foundation.* (2019). Margaretthatcher.org.
